questions.text: Which of the following is known as pacemaker of heart ?
questions.solution:
Sinuatrial node or SA node: It is known as the 'pacemaker' of the heart. It generates impulses at the rate of about 70-100 beats/min and initiates the heartbeat. It is horseshoe-shaped and is situated at the atriocaval junction in the upper part of the sulcus terminals. The impulse travels through the atrial wall to reach the AV node

Ref BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 1, Section 2 THORAX, Chapter 18 PERICARDIUM AND HEART page no. 297 and 298.

choices.text: Filling beyond 220ml causes a desire to micturate
Painful sensation starts when amount of urine in bladder reaches above 800 ml
Lining epithelium of bladder mucosa is transitional epithelium
Distance between ureteric orifice is 2.5cm apart in the empty bladder

questions.text: Find the false statement about Urinary Bladder
questions.solution:
Urinary bladder is a hollow viscus and acts as reservoir of urine.

When empty, it is tetrahedral in shape and is totally a pelvic organ. When distended, it becomes abdomino-pelvic organ and ovoid in shape.

The average capacity varies between 120-320 ml, with mean capacity being about 20 ml, Sense of filling of bladder first starts at filling of 40-150 ml, First desire for micturation usually appears at beyond 220ml filling. Painful sensations starts when amount of urine reaches above 500 ml. On collection of about 800 ml the micturition is beyond voluntary control

Ref. BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 2

Section 2 Abdomen and pelvis chapter 30 urinary bladder and urethra page no. 435

choices.text: Main site of absorption is through Arachnoid villi and granulations

questions.text: Find the false statement about CSF and it's circulation
questions.solution:
The major source of CSF is the choroidal plexus of all 4 ventricles, mainly in two lateral ventricles. Other sources of CSF are ependymal cells of the ventricles and the brain itself, via perivascular spaces. The total volume of CSF in an adult is about 125-150 ml. The rate of formation of CSF is about 500-550 ml/day. Thus the CSF is replaced 3-4 times every day.

From the lateral ventricles, CSF flows through the interventricular foramina (of monro) into the third ventricle From there, it flows through the aqueduct (of Sylvius) in the midbrain into the fourth ventricle. Finally, it flows out of the fourth ventricle through a median (magendie) and two lateral (Luschka) formina to circulate in the subarachnoid space around the brain and spinal cord.

  1. Csf is absorbed chiefly through arachnoid Villi and granules, thus drain into the cranial venous sinuses.
  2. Also absorbed partly by the perineural lymphatics around the first, second and eight cranial nerves.
  3. It is absorbed by veins related to spinal nerves.

Ref. BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 4, Chapter 2 meninges of the brain and cerebrospinal fluid Page no. 30, 31.

choices.text: 7th rib is the longest rib

questions.text: Find the false statement about ribs from the following
questions.solution:
There are 12 ribs on each side.

According to articulation with sternum the ribs are TRUE and false.

The first 7 ribs connected through their cartilages to the sternum are called TRUE ribs or vertebrosternal ribs.

Remaining 5 are false ribs.

The cartilages of eight, ninth and tenth ribs are joined to the next higher cartilage and are known as vertebrochondrial ribs.

The anterior ends of the eleventh and twelfth ribs are free and are called floating ribs or vertebral ribs.

According to morphology there are typical and atypical ribs Third to ninth ribs are typical ribs.

First two and last three are atypical ribs.

Ref. BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 1, Section 2 thorax chapter Bones and joints of thorax page no. 225

choices.text: Retrosternal cong. Hernia common in right side and lies between pericardium and right pleura
Commonest type of hernia is posterolateral hernia
Central hernia is left sided and due to rupture of foetal membranous diaphragm

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is true
questions.solution:
Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

  1. Retrosternal hernia- occurs through space between xiphoid and costal origins of the thoracoabdominal dihragm and formed of Morgagni. More common on right side
  2. Posterolateral hernia- Mc type, occurs through foramen of bochdalek situated at the periphery of diaphragm.
  3. Posterior hernia- failure of development of posterior part of diaphragm.
  4. Central hernia- rare and left sided.

Ref. BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 2

Section 2 Abdomen and pelvis Chapter 26 thoracoabdominal diaphragm page no. 390 and 391.

Carina is upper most part of trachea

questions.text: Find the false statement about Trachea
questions.solution:
Trachea has c- shaped rings which are 16 to 20 rings in number.

Upper end of trachea lies at lower border of cricoid cartilage, opposite the C-6 vertebra.

In live people, bifurcation lies at the lower border of T6 in female and lower border of T7 vertebra in males.

Nerve supply-

  • Parasympathetic- nerves through vagi and recurrent laryngeal nerves.(sensory and motor supply)
  • Sympathetic- fibers from the middle cervical ganglion along in thyroid arteries and are vasomotor.
  • Arterial supply- inferior thyroid artery

Ref. BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 1, Section 2, Chapter 20 trachea page no. 328, 329.

questions.text:
Which of the following statement is TRUE about pleura?
A. Nerve supply of parietal pleura is thoracic and phrenic nerves
B. Nerve supply of parietal pleura is sympathetic nerves from T2-T5 ganglia.
C. Nerve supply of visceral pleura is Parasympathetic to vagus nerve.
D. Nerve supply of visceral pleura is sympathetic nerves from T2-T5 ganglia.
questions.solution:
Nerve supply of visceral is is sympathetic nerves from T2-T5 ganglia and Parasympathetic from vagus.

Nerve supply of parietal pleura is thoracic and phrenic nerves

questions.text: Which of the following veins drain into the right atrium
questions.solution:
Coronary sinus

It opens in the posterior wall of right atrium, in the posterior part of coronary sulcus open in the right atrium between IVC and tricuspid orifices. The opening is guarded by semilunar valve of coronary sinus (Thebesian valve) which prevents regurgitation of blood into coronary sinus during atrial systole

Coronary sinus develops from body and left horn of sinus venosus 1) Tributaries of coronary sinus are:

Great cardiac vein that Lies in the anterior interventricular groove Left marginal vein Drains into it.

Middle cardiac vein - Lies in the posterior interventricular groove Posterior vein of left ventricle.

iv) Small cardiac vein It lies in the posterior part of coronary sulcus with RCA. Right marginal vein may sometimes open into small cardiac vein, more often, however, right marginal vein opens directly into right atrium

v) Oblique vein of left atrium (vein of marshall): It is continuous above with ligament of IVC. These two structures are embryological remnants of left common cardinal vein (duct of cuvier).

Anterior cardiac vein

  • It drains into right atrium piercing the anterior surface of the right atrium close to sulcus terminalis. Venae cordis minimi (smallest cardiac veins or Thebesian vein)
  • These are multiple small veins present in all four chambers of heart, more numerous on right side.

All the veins mentioned above drain into coronary sinns except anterior cardiac vein, venne cordis minimi and often right marginal vein. These three drain directly into right atrium

Ref. BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 1

Section 2 thorax Chapter 18 pericardium and heart page no. 296.

choices.text: Nurse's elbow - Subluxation of Radial head

questions.text: Which of the following is false about elbow joint
questions.solution:
Student's elbow (miner's elbow) is inflammation of olecranon bursa (olecranon bursitis),

A Pulled elbow (Nursemaid's elbow) is subluxation of radial head a Elbow dislocation is common in posterior direction, i.e. posterior dislocation.

Carrying angle is formed between the upper arm and forearm, when the elbow is extended and forearm is supinated. The normal carrying is 163' (some book gives a value of 11 for male and 14 for females). It is more in females. Carrying angle disappears in full flexion of elbow and pronation of forearm. Cubitus valgus is an increase in Carrying angle and cubitus varus is a decrease in carrying angle

Distension of elbow joint by an effusion occurs posteriorly because here the capsule is weak and the covering Deep fascia is thin.

Dislocation of elbow is usually occur posterior and is often associated with fracture of coracoid process. The triangular relationship between the olecranon process and the two humoral epicondyles is lost.

Section 1 upper part Chapter 10 joints of upper limb page no. 171, 172.

questions.text: The following test is used to test which muscle
questions.solution:
Muscles of the thenar eminence

Out of the three muscles of the thenar eminence, only two can be examined for their isolated action. These are Abductor pollicis brevis: The action of this muscle is to draw the thumb forwards at right angle to the As follows:

The patient is asked to lay his hand flat on the table with palm facing the ceiling. A pen is held above the thumb and the patient is aksed to touch the pen with tip of thumb. This is called the 'pen test' ii) Opponens pollicis: The function of this muscle is to appose the tip of the thumb to other fingers. Apposition is a swinging movement of the thumb across the palm and not a simple adduction. The latter movement is by the adductor pollicis muscle supplied by the ulnar nerve.

Ref. BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 1

Section 1 upper limb Chapter 9 forearm and hand page no. 136.

questions.text: A 20yr football player presents with excruciating pain in the right knee with history of trying to hit the ball hard he got injured, which ligament might be torn in the following presentation
questions.solution:
Injuries to cruciate ligaments are also common. The anterior cruciate ligament is more commonly damaged than the posterior. It may be injured in violent hyperextension of the knee or in anterior dislocation of the tibia. The posterior ligament is injured in posterior dislocation of the tibia. The injury may vary from simple sprain to complete tear. Tear of the ligaments leads to abnormal anteroposterior mobility

Injury to meniscus- strained in a slightly flexed knee, as in Kicking a football, the meniscus may get separated from the capsule, or may be torn longitudinally or transversly.

Injury to collateral ligaments- less common, may be produced my severe abduction and adduction strains.

Ref BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 2 Section 1 lower limb chapter 12 joints of lower limb page no. 173

questions.text: A 35yr male presents to the neurology clinic with inability to balance himself with loss of sensation of skin, further examination shows loss of position sense, he has history of unprotected sexual intercourse; what can be the diagnosis
questions.solution:
Tabes dorsalis occurs during tertiary syphilis. There is a degenerative loss of dorsal nerve roots and of posterior white column.

Feature is severe pain in lower limbs, as the disease occur in lower thoracic and lumbosacral segments. Lower limbs are mainly affected.

questions.text: Which condition is shown in the following Xray
questions.solution:
Spondylolisthesis

  • Sometimes the greater part of the fifth lumbar vertebra slips forwards over the sacrum.
  • Normally, the tendency to forward slipping is prevented by the fact that the inferior articular processes of the fifth lumbar vertebra lie behind the superior articular processes of the first sacral vertebra. At times, however, the inferior articular processes, spine and laminae of the fifth lumbar vertebra are separated from the rest of the vertebra (due to an anomaly in the mode of ossification). The body of the vertebra can now slip forwards leaving the separated parts behind.
  • Spondylolisthesis may be the cause of backache and of pain radiating along the course of the sciatic nerve known as sciatica.

Ref BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 2

Section 2 Abdomen and pelvis Chapter 1 introduction and osteology page no. 222 and 223.

questions.text: A patient came with severe abdominal pain, the attending surgeon suspected something based on the history and started palpating the abdomen, which organ is the surgeon palpating here
questions.solution:
The method is called Bimanual palpation of kidney

Kidney is palpated bimanually, with one hand placed in front and the other hand behind the flank. When enlarged, the lower pole of kidney becomes palpable on deep inspiration.

questions.text: Find the false statement about the following diverticulum in a 2yo child
questions.solution:
Meckel's diverticulum is the persistent proximal part of the vitellointestinal duct which normally disap pears during intrauterine life.

It follows ‘rule of 2’:- present in 2% subject, 2 inches (5 cm) long and is situated 2 feet (60 cm) proximal To ileocoecal valve

It is attached to antimesenteric border(193) of ileum. Its calibre is equal to that of the ileum. Its apex may be free or attached to umblicus or mesentery by a fibrous band

questions.text: Patient present with the wrist drop. Which of the nerve got injured in this patient?
questions.solution:
Fractures of the shaft of the humerus. This results in the weakness and loss of power of extension at the wrist (wrist drop) and sensory loss over a narrow strip on the back of forearm, and on the lateral side of the dorsum of the hand.

Wrist drop is quite disabling, because the patient cannot grip any object firmly in the hand without the synergistic action of the extensors.

Ref BD chaurasia human anatomy 9th edition volume 1

Section 1 upper limb Chapter 8 arm page no. 113
